name: Cereceda's conjecture
summary: Cereceda's conjecture is an unsolved problem in graph theory that states two different colorings of a d-degenerate graph using k colors can be transformed into each other by changing one vertex at a time in a number of steps that is quadratic in the size of the graph, provided that k is at least d+2. This is related to the diameter of the reconfiguration graph of colorings.
head: \(G\) is a \(d\)-degenerate graph on \(n\) vertices, and \(\alpha \) and \(\beta \) are two proper colorings of \(G\) using at most \(d+2\) colors
tail: then it is possible to transform \(\alpha \) into \( eta \) by changing the color of one vertex at a time, using a sequence of \(O(n^{2})\) steps (a number of steps at most quadratic in the number of vertices).Â
